Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Coastal consequences of engineered water control systems: the role of freshwater discharges in Florida's ongoing harmful algal bloom crises

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Several hundred tons of marine life have died along the Gulf shores of Florida since October 2017 from exposure to algal blooms known as a "red tide". The intensity of these blooms is believed to be related to nutrients in freshwater releases from Lake Okeechobee, a large inland lake in south-central Florida that is managed for flood prevention. However, strong scientific evidence to support the connection between the red tide and Lake Okeechobee water releases is lacking. The objective of this project is to collect, analyze, and model water quality data prior to and throughout major freshwater releases. These data will provide insight into cause-and-effect relationships between freshwater releases, and algal blooms. Findings from this study will directly inform management of one of the nation's most elaborate freshwater flood prevention systems, and support efforts to address the ecological emergency caused by red tide.

The central goals of the proposed work are to define the effects of human-managed freshwater control regimes on the magnitude and duration of coastal algal blooms, and transfer knowledge gained from this study to the public and decision-makers through education and outreach activities. We will investigate connections between Lake Okeechobee releases and coastal algal blooms of the species Karenia brevis using an interdisciplinary, data-intensive, multi-scale, and integrated fresh-marine systems approach. This effort necessitates rapid mobilization to collect targeted data on nutrient and algal loads along the Caloosahatchee River and Estuary that connects to Lake Okeechobee via canals. The project has the following objectives: (1) quantify spatial variability in water column conditions (water chemistry and phytoplankton community) across 13 sites from a fresh-marine gradient in southwest Florida prior to, during, and after Lake Okeechobee discharges, and (2) explain spatiotemporal variability in water column conditions as a function of physical, chemical, and biological factors. The combination of an ongoing red tide and imminent freshwater discharges from Lake Okeechobee creates a unique setting for investigating causal relationships between freshwater discharges and coastal algal blooms. To our knowledge, this study will be the first to couple multi-scale observations (i.e., in situ point observations, continuous monitoring data, and satellite imagery products) to analyze connections between freshwater discharges and marine red tides.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From October 2017 to October 2018, several hundred tons of marine life died along the southwest Gulf shores of Florida after being exposed to a marine harmful algal bloom known as a “red tide.” Red tides develop offshore and migrate to coastal waters via oceanic circulation. Once in coastal waters, red tides can last for different periods of time, like weeks or months, but the cause of this variation in bloom duration is not well understood. Freshwater discharges to coastal waters may partly explain variation in red tide duration, as freshwater discharges deliver nutrients and other phytoplankton that could serve as energy sources for red tide. The role of freshwater discharges in potentially contributing to red tide duration is compelling since water resource engineers design structures and management schedules that dictate the magnitude and frequency at which water is released to the coasts. Therefore, the central goals of this study were to investigate the potential role of freshwater inputs as a factor that partly explains differences in red tide duration, and communicate study findings to the public and decision-makers through education and outreach activities. We collected, analyzed, and modeled water quality variables across a range of freshwater discharge conditions. Specifically, across thirteen sites in the Caloosahatchee Estuary over ten sampling dates, we measured nutrient concentrations and stable nitrogen isotopes, and identified different species of phytoplankton that were present. During our field data collection efforts, we discovered an extensive hypoxic area in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, the severity of which had never been observed in this area and likely contributed to the large scale mortality event. We also uncovered intriguing relationships between the species that composes red tides (Karenia brevis), dissolved nutrient concentrations, and other types of phytoplankton. Whereas red tides are usually considered to be limited by the availability of nitrogen, we found that nitrogen levels in the estuary, particularly the offshore environment, were elevated, which indicated that present nutrient concentrations could result in phosphorus being more limiting to red tide growth than nitrogen. Picocyanobacteria, a small-celled class of blue-green algae, were inversely related to red tide, which may serve as empirical evidence that the phytoplankton composing red tides consume other types of phytoplankton. We also observed that nutrient concentrations decreased from the head of the estuary, where freshwater is discharged into the estuary, to the offshore environment. The decline in nutrient concentrations along the fresh-to-marine gradient of the estuary may be explained by phytoplankton nutrient uptake, indicating that analyses of nutrient availability for coastal red tides should also consider the role of phytoplankton as a potential nutrient source. During the project, we delivered our results through presentations given at public forums and professional conferences; in total, over 1000 people attended our research presentations. Findings from this study will inform management of one of the nation's most elaborate freshwater flood prevention systems (i.e. Lake Okeechobee), and support efforts to address ecological emergencies caused by red tides.
